question: What are genes related to B-cell immunodeficiency?
agent_answer:
The genes related to the disease "severe combined immunodeficiency, autosomal recessive, T cell-negative, B cell-negative, NK cell-positive," which is a form of B-cell immunodeficiency, include:

1. **RAG1** - [Gene RAG1 on Monarch Initiative](https://monarchinitiative.org/gene/HGNC:9831)
2. **RAG2** - [Gene RAG2 on Monarch Initiative](https://monarchinitiative.org/gene/HGNC:9832)

These genes have a causal relationship with the disease, meaning mutations in these genes are known to cause the condition.

agent_answer_provenance.content: {"results": [{"id": "MONDO:0035454", "name": "B-cell immunodeficiency-limb anomaly-urogenital malformation syndrome", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": null}, {"id": "MONDO:0012243", "name": "B-cell immunodeficiency, distal limb anomalies, and urogenital malformations", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": null}, {"id": "MONDO:0011086", "name": "severe combined immunodeficiency, autosomal recessive, T cell-negative, B cell-negative, NK cell-positive", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": "A rare, genetic T-B- severe combined immunodeficiency disorder due to null mutations in recombination activating gene (RAG) 1 and/or RAG2 resulting in less than 1% of wild type V(D)J recombination activity. Patients present with neonatal onset of life-threatening, severe, recurrent infections by opportunistic fungal, viral and bacterial micro-organisms, as well as skin rashes, chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive and fever. Immunologic observations include profound T- and B-cell lymphopenia, normal NK counts and low or absent serum immunoglobulins; some patients may have eosinophilia."}, {"id": "MONDO:0015707", "name": "obsolete DNA repair defect other than combined T-cell and B-cell immunodeficiencies", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": null}, {"id": "MONDO:0014487", "name": "congenital sideroblastic anemia-B-cell immunodeficiency-periodic fever-developmental delay syndrome", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": "Congenital sideroblastic anemia -B cell immunodeficiency- periodic fever-developmental delay syndrome is a form of constitutional sideroblastic anemia, characterized by severe microcytic anemia, B-cell lymphopenia, panhypogammaglobulinemia and variable neurodegeneration. The disease presents in infancy with recurrent febrile illnesses, gastrointestinal disturbances, developmental delay, seizures, ataxia and sensorineural deafness. Most patients require regular blood transfusion, iron chelation, and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) replacement. Stem cell transplantation has been reported to be successful."}, {"id": "MONDO:0033683", "name": "congenital progressive bone marrow failure-B-cell immunodeficiency-skeletal dysplasia syndrome", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": null}, {"id": "MONDO:0018038", "name": "obsolete immunodeficiency with isotype or light chain deficiencies with normal number of B-cells", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": null}, {"id": "MONDO:0007064", "name": "severe combined immunodeficiency, autosomal recessive, T cell-negative, B cell-negative, NK cell-negative, due to adenosine deaminase deficiency", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": "A form of SCID characterized by profound lymphopenia and very low immunoglobulin levels of all isotypes resulting in severe and recurrent opportunistic infections."}, {"id": "MONDO:0018040", "name": "obsolete immunodeficiency with severe reduction in serum IgG and IgA with normal/elevated IgM and normal number of B-cells", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": null}, {"id": "MONDO:0015131", "name": "combined immunodeficiency", "categories": ["biolink:Disease"], "description": "A broad classification of inherited disorders presenting at birth that affect both the cell-mediated and humoral aspects of the immune response. Circulating numbers of B lymphocytes, T lymphocytes and NK cells are variable but where present do not function properly. Susceptibility to infection is the primary concern."}], "total": 26}
